title: Sinusoidal Function Modeling - Windmill - Part A

content.question: Part A The graph of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>h</mn> </math> and its dashed midline for two full cycles is shown. Five points, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>F</mn> </math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>G</mn> </math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>J</mn> </math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>K</mn> </math>, and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>P</mn> </math>, are labeled on the graph. No scale is indicated, and no axes are presented. Determine possible coordinates <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>,</mo> <mi>h</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3C87@</annotation> </semantics> </math> for the five points: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>F</mn> </math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>G</mn> </math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>J</mn> </math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>K</mn> </math>, and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>P</mn> </math> . Moving from left to right: Point F is at a maximum point. Point G is on the midline. Point J is at a minimum point. Point K is on the midline. Point P is at a maximum point.

topic.text: 3.7: Sinusoidal Function Context and Data Modeling

skill.text: Skill 2.B: Construct equivalent graphical, numerical, analytical, and verbal representations of functions that are useful in a given mathematical or applied context, with and without technology.
